I am starting a PhD in Computer Science this Spring at CU Boulder, working under the supervision of Katharina Kann in the NALA lab.
Natural Language Processing
Machines play an important role in so many day-to-day interactions, and the ways in which we communicate with them are nuanced to be sure. I work in NLP; at the intersection of language and computer science, with applications that support such technologies as automatic translation, speech to text transcription, and the information extraction.
Linguistics
The languages spoken by humans have latent structures that we rely on in order to understand each other, however, it is incredibly difficult to identify what those structures are. I have a theoretical background in linguistics, which deals with such topics as categorizing the typological features of languages universally, the study of sound structures, and the nuances of expressing meaning.
Software Development
My professional background in web development sometimes persists as just a hobby. But it provides me with the tools that I need in order to support so many projects that are driven by my other interests. Web browsers are a GUI that almost everyone is comfortable working in, and making applications and information accessible over the internet, in a uniform interface is incredibly important. Other aspects of software engineering also play a large role in the way that I approach research.
